title: 114_hr470
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015". It includes findings and definitions. The Act, known as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015", contains findings by Congress regarding certain National Forest System land in Georgia that is inefficient to manage or has lost its value. The Act authorizes the sale of this land for the public interest, with proceeds used by the Forest Service to purchase land for National Forest purposes in Georgia. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. Additionally, the Act grants land conveyance authority. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange rights, title, and interest of the United States in 30 tracts of National Forest System land totaling approximately 3,841 acres in Georgia. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange approximately 3,841 acres of National Forest System land in Georgia, as depicted on maps dated September 24, 2013. The maps will be available for public inspection until the land is sold or exchanged, and the Secretary may modify the boundaries as needed. Forest Supervisor, Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest, may modify boundaries based on land management considerations. Land sold under this Act will be conveyed by quitclaim deed, with the Secretary reserving rights-of-way or other interests as needed for management or public interest protection. The Secretary may reserve rights-of-way or other interests in land sold under this Act for management or public interest protection. Land cannot be sold for less than market value, determined by appraisal or competitive bid, following specific appraisal standards. Appraisal for land sales must adhere to specific standards and be approved by the Secretary. Consideration for sales must be paid in cash, and the Secretary can accept cash equalization payments exceeding 25% of the land value for exchanges. The Secretary can accept cash equalization payments exceeding 25% of the land value for exchanges and may sell land through public or private sales, including competitive auctions. The Secretary has the authority to make solicitations for the sale or exchange of land, reject inadequate offers, use brokers or third parties for land disposition, and pay commissions from sale proceeds. SEC. 4 of the Act addresses the treatment of proceeds from authorized sales. Proceeds are deposited into a specific fund and are available to the Secretary for land acquisition in Georgia without further appropriation. Funds cannot be used to acquire land without the owner's written consent.
